Award.AwardTitle: Gaining insights into the physiology of neutrophilic, iron-oxidizing chemolithoautotrophs.
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2015, Broadening Participation. The fellowship supports a research and training plan in a host laboratory for the Fellow and a plan to broaden participation of groups under-represented in science. The title of the research plan for this fellowship to Dr. Roman A. Barco is "Gaining insights into the physiology of autotrophic, iron-oxidizing microorganisms." The host institutions for this fellowship are Bigelow Laboratory for Ocean Sciences (BLOS) and the University of Southern California (USC). The sponsoring scientists are Dr. David Emerson (lead sponsor at BLOS) and Dr. Kenneth Nealson (co-sponsor at USC).

The phylum Proteobacteria comprises a large and varied group of bacteria, including many pathogens but also many of benefit to humans, e.g., nitrogen-fixing bacteria crucial to agriculture. A class within the Proteobacteria phylum, the Zetaproteobacteria, plays a key role in the global iron cycle. All the Zetaproteobacteria that have been isolated to date obtain energy by oxidizing iron. They are both abundant and very active in marine environments with low concentrations of oxygen and with conditions that fall between acid and basic pH, known as circumneutral pH (pH 6 to 8). In addition to oxidizing iron, they also fix carbon, making them primary producers (autotrophs) in marine habitats associated with high iron content, such as hydrothermal vents, the oceanic crust and the deep marine subsurface. Yet despite these important environmental roles, their physiology has not been elucidated and requires further study. Conveniently, a Zetaproteobacteria relative has been isolated that does not require iron for its growth and, by comparison with the wild type, allows for identification of the proteins that carry out iron oxidation. A group of bacteria from the Gammaproteobacteria class, Thiomicrospira, obtains energy by oxidizing sulfur. Its genome has been sequenced, making it possible to compare the physiology of iron and sulfur oxidizers at the most basic level. Such analysis conducted during this fellowship promises useful insights into the mechanisms of iron-oxidation across different classes of the Proteobacteria phylum. Both of these types of bacteria are potentially useful in a number of biotechnology applications, including bioremediation.

Training goals for the fellowship include acquiring programming skills for bioinformatics, especially for analyzing next-generation sequencing data and learning techniques in electromicrobiology, the use of electrodes to enrich and isolate microorganisms. The Fellow serves as a role model and mentor to undergraduate students at both host institutions and collaborates with the Center for Dark Energy Biosphere Investigations via the Community College Connections (CCC) program. The CCC program targets community colleges in Los Angeles, CA and surrounding areas, to disseminate information about environmental microbiology and how it links to other scientific fields such as geology, chemistry, and oceanography.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biological iron oxidation at neutral pH, in the presence of oxygen, is one of the most poorly understood of the major lithotrophic metabolisms in the microbial world, despite the fact that the bacteria that catalyze this process are abundant and important to the global iron cycle. The goals of this project were: (a) to gain knowledge about the active components of the electron transport chain of Zetaproteobacterium TAG-1, an iron-oxidizing microbe that is unique in having the ability to grow on hydrogen as an alternative; (b) to sequence and analyze the genome of a putative novel Fe-oxidizing Thiomicrospira strain SC-1 (Gammaproteobacteria), which is the first Fe-oxidizing species in a genus that has been known only for S oxidation and is relevant to the marine deep subsurface (c) to fully characterize strain SC-1 and, (d) to learn and utilize new electromicrobiological methods for the isolation and growth of new FeOB from the deep subsurface environment, (e) to enrich for neutrophilic FeOB by in-situ colonization of Fe-bearing minerals (e.g. pyrite and pyrrhotite) and (f) to gain training in professional, academic development including teaching. 

Some key outcomes are described in detail in two different manuscripts authored by the PI that were published in Environmental Microbiology (Barco et al., 2017) and Frontiers in Microbiology (He et al., 2017; as co-author). In Barco et al. (2017), it was revealed via in-situ incubations that in coastal sediments, iron-sulfide minerals could be niches for autotrophic (carbon-fixing) microbial communities that use iron or sulfur as sources of energy. It was also revealed that Thiomicrospira, which has been known for sulfur oxidation for decades, can actually also grow with iron as an energy source. In a separate manuscript, genomes from different types of iron-oxidizing microbes were analyzed to identify conserved genes and potential genetic markers for the biological function of iron-oxidation. This work was part of a collaboration with Dr. Shaomei He and Dr, Eric Roden from the University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI. 

Other key outcomes are pending publication. They include the physiological and metabolic characterization of the novel iron-oxidizing Thiomicrospira sp. SC-1, the first example of a marine microbe that displays the ability to switch between iron and sulfur autotrophy. SC-1's genome was analyzed revealing Calvin cycle genes, sulfur oxidation (sox) genes, and remarkably, iron oxidation genes. Analysis of the proteome of Zetaproteobacterium sp. TAG-1 has been completed. Genes that were up-regulated under iron-oxidizing and hydrogen-oxidizing conditions were identified. The comparative proteomics project was complemented by experiments with TAG-1 growing on electrochemical reactors and which show uptake of electrons from cathodes. These results suggest that TAG-1 is equipped with proteins on the outer membrane that can accept these electrons. The PI has also investigated colonization of autotrophic communities on iron-sulfide minerals in coastal environments, with the major finding that there is active microbial succession of the autotrophic microbial community during early colonization of these minerals. Major microbial players include Zetaproteobacteria, Epsilonproteobacteria, and unclassified Gammaproteobacteria. A putative novel iron-oxidizing microorganism, Zetaproteobacterium sp. EBB-1 was isolated from this work. EBB-1's genome was successfully sequenced. The work described above influenced the development by the PI of a technique to demarcate taxonomic genera involving genomic indices, which could be applied in any field investigating microbes (e.g., medical field).

In the summers of 2016 and 2017, the PI supervised and mentored a total of 10 community college students as part of the Community College Cultivation Cohort, an NSF-funded Research Experience for Undergraduates. Eight of these students helped characterize the physiology, metabolism, phylogeny, and genomic potential of Thiomicrospira sp. SC-1. The PI also participated in the Chief-Scientist training cruise, a University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS) program that instructs early career scientists at-sea and on-shore (via telepresence) on how to properly plan for research and education utilizing UNOLS vessels (e.g. submersible Alvin).
